title: 733-A
statement: A. Grasshopper And the Stringtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputOne day, the Grasshopper was jumping on the lawn and found a piece of paper with a string. Grasshopper became interested what is the minimumjump abilityhe should have in order to be able to reach the far end of the string, jumping only on vowels of the English alphabet.Jump abilityis the maximum possible length of his jump.Formally, consider that at the begginning the Grasshopper is located directly in front of the leftmost character of the string. His goal is to reach the position right after the rightmost character of the string. In one jump the Grasshopper could jump to the right any distance from1to the value of hisjump ability.The picture corresponds to the first example.The following letters are vowels: 'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U' and 'Y'.InputThe first line contains non-empty string consisting of capital English letters. It is guaranteed that the length of the string does not exceed 100.OutputPrint single integeraâ€” the minimumjump abilityof the Grasshopper (in the number of symbols) that is needed to overcome the given string, jumping only on vowels.ExamplesInputABABBBACFEYUKOTTOutput4InputAAAOutput1

processed.result: You are given a string consisting of capital English letters.  Find the minimum number of positions the Grasshopper must be able to jump in order to reach the end of the string, given that the Grasshopper can only jump on vowels ('A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U', and 'Y'). The Grasshopper starts at the beginning of the string.

Given a string of letters, find the smallest number of steps you need to take to reach the end of the string, where each step can be any length from 1 to a maximum value. You can only step on letters that are vowels (A, E, I, O, U, Y).
